ARGUMENT.</br>Penardo's ayde is cum to lat</br>The toun is set on fyre</br>He followes on the Enemie</br>Revenge is his desyre</br>A visione in his sleip appeirs</br>The whiche he does declear</br>Beneth Apollo's altar, He</br>Hes found an armour fair

Ambitioune is a passioune woundrous strong</br>Of noble courage and of mightie force</br>Whiche captive leads all galant spreits along</br>And even the strongest passions does enforce</br>Yea love it self whiche seemeth to contend</br>Yet oft ambitione victor proves in end.

Ambitione is an flamme that burns the mynd</br>With endles drouth still thristing efter glorye</br>A blind excessive gredine (of kynd)</br>To be imbost in tym's eternall storie</br>Still hunting after greatnes that we sie</br>Ambitione never satisfied to be.

Ambition heigh is not a Passione feat</br>For baseborne brain's, or wordlie small attemp's</br>Renoune and glorie stoups not to such bait</br>Those ar not capable but ar contemp's</br>For proud ambitioune beats and casts them doune</br>Whill as they seik praise, glory, and renoune.

Ambitione after gaine does not persue</br>Nor actions reapping profeit does it cair</br>But ay wheir dreidfull danger does ensu</br>Difficult strainge unusuall and rare</br>Ev'ne there, ambitione hunts for glorie ever</br>For base and wordlie gaine it caireth never.

This passione Prince Penardo did bereave</br>Of whom we write this following historie</br>Who thirsting after honor seem'd to leave</br>A famous name in Glorious memorie</br>In him ambitione, crewell warre susteind</br>Gainst love, and famous victorie obtaind

Who as we said recei'd that armie small</br>Wheir with he should releive Beotias neid</br>But Sigismundi (the citie for to thral)</br>Haid send the Transilvaniane Prince with speid</br>Whoes valarous renoune to heavne did munt</br>Wheir for Penardo with ambitione brunt,

He freat's, he froun's, he longs to reave the croune</br>Of fame and glory from Phelastons head</br>And set it on his owne, whith great renoune</br>To beir it through the world unconquered</br>More greif he fynds when one goes him before</br>Then joy in conquing of a thousand skore.

Now he right glade in gaining of this chairge</br>Tuo dayes led furth his army one the way</br>At last drew neir and on a plaine right large</br>Wold neids refresh his wearie men a day</br>And then he sends, to learne, to vew to kno</br>Th' estate, the place, the number of his foe.

When Phebus drinsh't his sylver shyning hair</br>In Thetis lape they saw a cloud aspyre</br>Whoes smook send suddane darknes throw the aer</br>Wherin appeird reid flashing flamm's of fyre</br>As if the earthe out of her bowells wyde</br>Had send to choak the loftie heavens for pryde.

While as the armie vewing stoode amaiz'd</br>Whoes hautie hearts no fear could harbor in</br>Yeit vew's with fear and fearing still they gaz'd</br>Their quyet murmur made a fearfull dine</br>At last the skoutts returning told ye treuth</br>Which mov'd them all to woe, to care, to reuth.

Know mightie Prince your enemies ar gone</br>Becaus they have fulfild their fearce desyre</br>For they have raysd the walls of yonder toun</br>And set it all with skoarching flamm's a fyre</br>Touns tours and walls in crewell fyre doth burne</br>Men, women, babs, by bloodie swords ar torne.

This was the caus of their destructione loe</br>They feard the Prince his ayde should come too lait</br>And laiking souldiours on their wall's to show</br>For their defence agains their crewell fate</br>Within a forrest full of lack's and fenn's</br>Thre hundreth robers lay in caves and denns.

The cheif of these was once a citizene</br>Who playing bancker out, his goods hade lost</br>Whairfore he hyed him to the Robers dene</br>Who chus'd him chiftane of their theevishe host</br>Him hyr'd they straight with soum's of Indiane gold</br>To guarde their walls and to defend their Hold

But he who had no pitie nor regaird</br>Unto their lywes but only to their gold</br>Agreid by privie letter's for reward</br>And to Phelaston has the citie sold</br>Ah haples wretch that canst destroy and kill</br>Men at thy mercie, thy command, and will.

Evne as the mightie marlion mounts the sky</br>And soares one loftie wing's with gaizing eyes</br>At last the chirming larke she does espy</br>Cheif chanter in the queir of all that flies</br>Whose hollow throat, sends furth a thousand sounds</br>To pearce the azure vaults that back redounds,

Her shrill sweit notts, with silent blowing breath</br>Now seing her fearce enemie aspyre</br>Pearcing the emptie aer to flie from death</br>Whil to prolong she mounteth, still the hyer</br>Bot with sad looks, whill thus she bids adue</br>Their she a wearie traveler does vew.

Whoes hart she oft had cheird with chirming cleir</br>Awaking him frome drousie sleip to ryse</br>And warnd him that Apollos light drew neir</br>And in his long'sum jorney did devyse</br>New not's wheiron she curious descant founds</br>Filling his ears with diapason sounds

And thinking now that he wold thankfull be</br>She hyes fast doune and seiks his ayde to beild her</br>With feirfull shreiks does in his besome flie</br>Glad that she song to him who now does sheild her</br>But he whoes hairt no pitie harbours loe</br>Delivers her unto her mortall foe.

So did this fructe of ill this welth of woe</br>This curse of havene in whoe unnaturall hart</br>No pitie could have place but to her foe</br>The citie yelds (for this her good desert)</br>That oft had song sweit not's of educatione</br>To draw him from his haples constellatione

Ev'ne so the ravening wolfe by simple goat</br>Broght up, with love, with travell, care, and, paine</br>And feid upon her teat (such is her loat)</br>Till strength and force and vigour he retaine</br>Then he whome she brought up so cairfullie</br>Her deith, her grave, her sepulchre must be

The Prince that pitied suche a sore mischance</br>Admiring much this monstrous crueltie</br>Swoor in a rage his armie to advance</br>Till he reveng'd Boeotias miserie</br>Which did inrol his praise above the skyes</br>His fame, woorth, valour, woundrous victories.

When Phebus harbinger in crimsone cled</br>Chaic'd donne to Hell nights hated hew abhorde</br>The flower that murn's for Phebus absence spred</br>Her beautie furthe and smyl's upone her Lord</br>Whoes birning beams and lyfe infusing rayes</br>Conforts the Earth and beautifieis ye skyes

Then through the campe a murmur gane to ryse</br>All cryes for armes the trumpets sounds aloud</br>Ther sturdie coursars courage loudly brayes</br>And seemd to cry for loftie sydars proud</br>They forward march't whith joy and great delight</br>Their willing mynds made heavie armour light

And martching thus with suche a restles pace</br>Thre dayes three nights, at last they com in sight</br>Of their proud foes who heiring of their chaice</br>Had lyk desyre lyrk will to prove their might</br>Shouts, clamours, cryes, on evrye syd descry</br>Their will, desyre, and hope of victory.

And yit Phelaston lyk ane champioune wyse</br>Forecasting perrells in his throught alone</br>Feard that Penardo's hardie enterpryse</br>Was but a craftie traine to draw him on</br>And that the armie in some corner lay</br>His campe upone a suddane to betreay

Yet being of a mightie galant mynd</br>He sham'd to flie at his imaginatione</br>Wheir fore in hast to Athens did he send</br>Wheir Brando lay at seige to show the fashione</br>Brando, the reull ov'r Servia did hold</br>Stout, hardy wight adventorous and bold

Which when he hard his seige he rais'd in hast</br>And to the Prince Phelaston martch'd along</br>Now know that in his camp their was at least</br>One horse and fute sum tuentie thousand strong</br>To Sigismund those newes he shortlie sends</br>Who rais'd his seige frome Thebs and thither wends.

Now Primum mobile hade drawen the light</br>With his swift course out of our Hemispere</br>And spred the jeatblack mantle of the night</br>That summonds all the creatures with fear</br>Unto their rest then for to be thair sheild</br>They built a canves citie on the feild

Whil thus he had incamped in their sight</br>Set furth his watch his campe intrinshit strong</br>This Campioune caus'd disarme them all that night</br>For their refreshment after jorney long</br>After repast the Prince to sleip is gone</br>And in his sleip appeird this visione.

A virgine Nymphe (whoes beautie dimd the sky)</br>With saddest looks with sobs with sighs with tears</br>So sorowfull the seem'd with weipping ey</br>Led by tuo feinds of Pluto's griesly fears</br>Her body seem'd all dyed in crimsone blood</br>Her garment skoarch'd in flamm's of hellish brood.

Thus leading her hard by him (as he thought)</br>She cryd o sweitt Penardo lend thy ayde</br>Whoes only strength the fates decree has wrought</br>To end the ceasles torments of a Mayde</br>Wheirat him thought he start with suddane fear</br>Drawing his brand those hellishe feinds to tear.

But then with myldest speeche she sayd no more</br>Thy willingnes suffeizeth at this tyme</br>A greatter danger thow must pas before</br>Thy happie ayde geve end unto my cryme</br>But mightie Jove in danger, warre, and stryfe</br>Preserve thy fame, thy honor, and thy lyfe.

Not farr their stands within a pleasant vaill</br>Ane altar built at Agamemnons cost</br>In honor of fair Pallas sacred Cell</br>When he was captain of the Graetiane host</br>Their, lyes a sword, a sheild, ane armour fair</br>Of woorth, of wounder, and of vertue rare.

Feight not before yow have this armour on</br>Whose woorth shall much advance thy wondrous fame</br>For know this much before tuo dayes by gone</br>That Pluto has conspyrt to spoyle thy name.</br>For he has send the Feinds in legions foorth</br>To seik to shame, to wrack, to staine, thy woorth.

And thus she vanisht quyt out of his sight</br>He wakeing one a suddane from his sleip</br>Thought this to be a fantasie too light</br>That from his humor'd braine did fondlie creip</br>Yet warlie did his thoughts one witt attend</br>Weying if good or ill theron depend.

Aurora in her purple robe arose</br>Warning proud Titan for to light the day</br>And drew, the courtens that did him disclose</br>In Thetis lovelie armes that dalleing lay</br>Who stole away and in the gloomie East</br>Reard up above the Earth his flamming crest.

How soone the Prince espyit his goldine light</br>He cald for Mandadorus Prince of Mesone</br>This Mandadorus was of greattest might</br>Of all his subjects save the Duik of Thesone</br>To him he told his dreame who said your grace</br>May try't and trying lett the trueth have place.

Wheirfore he send and from his antient roume</br>Causd raise the altar wheir they fand a stone</br>Of Alabastre builded lyk a Toumbe</br>In greik sum letters wer ingraft theron</br>Those we ethe words (ingraph't in gold so fyne</br>That now as first their lustre seem'd to shyne.

This pretious stone ane armour does retain</br>Whose woundrous woorth as yit shal no man know</br>Untill the Spreit of them that lives in pain</br>Evne to a mightie stranger shaell them show</br>Who with the same recalls relents, releifs,</br>Thrie Souls from paine, from death, from Hells mischeifs

Hid was the meaning darck the sentence seemd</br>Of all the trueth they could not type the ground</br>But this fair costlie armour as they deemd</br>Had at the famous wars of Troy beine found</br>Which grave and wyse Cassandra had invented</br>For Paris, Troys feirce fall to have prevented.

Lo thus it was she knowing by her art</br>The ruine of heavn threatning Troy drew neir</br>And that proud Paris his uniust desert</br>Should be the caus of such an endles weir</br>To him by art she had this armour wrought</br>That all the Gods decree might turne to nought,

For she discending to the lowest Hells</br>Her mightie powre in magick force she shew</br>The greislie Ghosts stood trembling whill she tells</br>Her will in frameing of this armour new</br>Loath to provyd remorce, remeid, releif</br>Who joy'd in blood, warre, murther, and mischeif.

Yitt fear them forc't they durst not disobey</br>Her mightie art and all-commanding will</br>For she with strainge characters could a lay</br>The pains of Hell from punishment of ill</br>Yea she the Suns diurnall course culd stay</br>And turne to darkest night the brightest day.

And whill these feinds this armour fyne did make</br>They forgd the metall first in Aetnas flame</br>And temperd it into the Stygiane lake</br>With herbs of woundrous force amongs't the same</br>That mightie strong inchantments can with stand</br>Yea sword, and fyre, and water, can command.

Joves douchter brought king Agamemnon furth</br>When she with them returning was to Troy</br>Who seing them of such a woundrous woorth</br>Bereft the grave Cassandra of her joy</br>Who had with herbs and flams of Flegitone</br>Composd a strange and admirable stone.

Which secreitlie she in this armour sett</br>Whose vertue was his owner for to stay</br>From love, and amorous desyr's to lett</br>Arming the hart gainst all venereall play</br>For princelie Paris she devys'd this traine</br>That he might render Helene back againe.
